ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Best course I've ever taken at Yale. By far.
Learned how to use Stata, conduct my own empirical research, run focus groups, and write an economic paper.

I learned about the financial crisis, developed my research and writing skills, and wrote a report about the background, outcomes, designs of the policy and controversies of the Northern Rock Deposit Guarantee, and Liquidity Support Facility that were put in place in 2007.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I learned a lot about the crisis of 2008, specifically in the UK. This case enabled me to look into the type of government interventions that could be implemented to solve, for example, liquidity difficulties at financial institutions. The YPFS will have great impact in the way we deal with future crises, and this directed studies was a great way to participate in it, and contribute to the much-needed research on macroprudential financial regulation that still needs to be done.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This was an amazing study to do, to learn about the financial crisis and delve into case studies of government interventions, and to contribute to a program that will expand and help the scholarly and regulatory community in such an impactful way.
